ai-mn146:1.2_0: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
ai-mn146:2.1_0: Then Mahāpajāpatī Gotamī together with around five hundred monks.
ai-mn146:2.1_1: and after approaching and worshipping the Fortunate One, he stood on one side.
ai-mn146:2.1_2: While standing on one side Mahāpajāpatī Gotamī said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-mn146:2.3_0: the Fortunate One should instruct the nuns, reverend Sir,
ai-mn146:2.4_0: Please give the nuns a Dhamma talk.”
ai-mn146:3.1_0: Now at that time the senior monks were taking turns to advise the nuns.
ai-mn146:3.2_0: But Venerable Nandaka didn’t want to take his turn.
ai-mn146:3.3_0: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Ānanda,
ai-mn146:3.6_0: This Venerable Nandaka is able to instruct the nuns.”
ai-mn146:4.1_0: Then the Fortunate One addressed the venerable Nandaka,
ai-mn146:4.5_0: “Yes, sir,” replied Nandaka. Then, in the morning, he robed up and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
ai-mn146:4.6_0: Then, after the meal, on his return from alms-round, he went to his own king’s monastery.
ai-mn146:4.7_0: Those nuns saw him coming off in the distance,
ai-mn146:4.8_0: so they spread out a seat and placed water for washing the feet.
ai-mn146:4.9_0: Nandaka sat down on the seat spread out,
ai-mn146:4.11_0: Those nuns bowed, and sat down to one side.
ai-mn146:4.12_0: While sitting on one side venerable Nandaka said this to those nuns:
ai-mn146:5.1_0: “Sisters, this will be a talk in which I put questions,
ai-mn146:5.2_0: herein, when you understand, you should say: ‘We don’t understand.’
ai-mn146:5.3_0: But if for you there is doubt or uncertainty herein you should ask in return:
ai-mn146:5.4_0: ‘Why, sir, does it say this? What does that mean?’”
ai-mn146:5.5_0: “We’re already delighted and satisfied with Venerable Nandaka, since he invites us like this.”
ai-mn146:6.2_0: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”
ai-mn146:6.4_0: “But if they're impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-mn146:6.6_0: “But if they're impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-mn146:6.7_0: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-mn146:6.12_0: Is the nose permanent or impermanent?”
ai-mn146:6.20_0: “But if they're impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-mn146:6.22_0: “But if they're impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-mn146:6.23_0: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-mn146:6.26_0: Because we have already truly seen this with right wisdom:
ai-mn146:6.27_0: ‘So these six interior sense fields are impermanent.’”
ai-mn146:6.29_0: That’s how it is for a noble disciple who truly sees with right wisdom.
ai-mn146:7.4_0: “But if they're impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-mn146:7.6_0: “But if they're impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-mn146:7.7_0: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-mn146:7.20_0: “But if they're impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-mn146:7.22_0: “But if they're impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-mn146:7.23_0: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-mn146:7.26_0: Because we have already truly seen this with right wisdom:
ai-mn146:7.27_0: ‘So these six exterior sense fields are impermanent.’”
ai-mn146:7.29_0: That’s how it is for a noble disciple who truly sees with right wisdom.
ai-mn146:8.4_0: “But if they're impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-mn146:8.6_0: “But if they're impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-mn146:8.7_0: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-mn146:8.19_0: “But if they're impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-mn146:8.21_0: “But if they're impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-mn146:8.22_0: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-mn146:8.25_0: Because we have already truly seen this with right wisdom:
ai-mn146:8.26_0: ‘So these six classes of consciousness are impermanent.’”
ai-mn146:8.28_0: That’s how it is for a noble disciple who truly sees with right wisdom.
ai-mn146:9.1_0: Suppose there was an oil lamp burning. The oil, wick, flame, and light were all impermanent and perishable.
ai-mn146:9.2_0: He who would say this, sisters:
ai-mn146:9.3_0: ‘For this oil lamp that is burning the oil, wick, and changeable,
ai-mn146:9.4_0: But the light is permanent, lasting, eternal, and imperishable.’
ai-mn146:9.8_0: Because that oil lamp’s oil, wick, and flame are all impermanent and perishable,
ai-mn146:9.10_0: “In the same way, suppose someone was to say:
ai-mn146:9.11_0: ‘These six interior sense fields are impermanent.
ai-mn146:9.12_0: But the feeling—whether pleasant, painful, or neutral—that I experience due to these six fields is permanent, lasting, eternal, and imperishable.’
ai-mn146:9.16_0: Because each kind of feeling arises dependent on the corresponding condition.
ai-mn146:9.17_0: When the corresponding condition ceases, the appropriate feeling ceases.”
ai-mn146:9.19_0: That’s how it is for a noble disciple who truly sees with right wisdom.
ai-mn146:10.1_0: Suppose there was a large tree standing with heartwood. The roots, trunk, and branches and leaves are all impermanent and perishable.
ai-mn146:10.2_0: He who would say this, sisters:
ai-mn146:10.3_0: ‘There’s a large tree standing with heartwood. The roots, trunk, and branches and leaves are all impermanent and perishable. But the shadow is permanent, lasting, eternal, and imperishable.’
ai-mn146:10.7_0: Because that large tree’s roots, trunk, and branches and leaves are all impermanent and perishable,
ai-mn146:10.8_0: what to say of its shadow being impermanent and changeable?”
ai-mn146:10.9_0: “In the same way, suppose someone was to say:
ai-mn146:10.10_0: ‘These six exterior sense fields are impermanent.
ai-mn146:10.11_0: But the feeling—whether pleasant, painful, or neutral—that I experience due to these six exterior sense fields is permanent, lasting, eternal, and imperishable.’
ai-mn146:10.15_0: Because each kind of feeling arises dependent on the corresponding condition.
ai-mn146:10.16_0: When the corresponding condition ceases, the appropriate feeling ceases.”
ai-mn146:10.18_0: That’s how it is for a noble disciple who truly sees with right wisdom.
ai-mn146:11.1_0: Suppose a deft butcher or their apprentice was to kill a cow and carve it with a sharp meat cleaver. Without damaging the flesh inside or the hide outside,
ai-mn146:11.2_0: they’d cut, carve, sever, and slice through the connecting tendons, sinews, and ligaments,
ai-mn146:11.3_0: and then peel off the outer hide. Then they’d wrap that cow up in that very same hide and say:
ai-mn146:11.4_0: ‘This cow is joined to its hide just like before.’
ai-mn146:11.8_0: For that a deft butcher or their apprentice was to kill a cow and carve it with a sharp meat cleaver.
ai-mn146:11.9_0: they’d cut, carve, sever, and slice through the connecting tendons, sinews, and ligaments,
ai-mn146:11.10_0: and then peel off the outer hide. Then they’d wrap that cow up in that very same hide and say:
ai-mn146:11.11_0: ‘This cow is joined to its hide just like before.’
ai-mn146:11.12_0: still that cow is not joined to that hide.”
ai-mn146:12.1_0: “I’ve made up this simile to make a point.
ai-mn146:12.2_0: and this is the meaning here:
ai-mn146:12.3_0: ‘The interior sense fields’ is a term for the six interior sense fields.
ai-mn146:12.4_0: ‘The outer hide’ is a term for the six exterior sense fields.
ai-mn146:12.5_0: ‘The connecting tendons, sinews, and ligaments’ is a term for greed and relishing.
ai-mn146:12.6_0: ‘A sharp meat cleaver’ is a term for noble wisdom.
ai-mn146:12.7_0: And it is that noble wisdom which cuts, carves, severs, and slices the connecting corruption, fetter, and bond.
ai-mn146:13.1_0: Sisters, by developing and cultivating these seven awakening factors, a mendicant realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
ai-mn146:13.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by seven?
ai-mn146:13.3_0: It’s when a mendicant develops the awakening factors of mindfulness,
ai-mn146:13.4_0: They develop the awakening factor of investigation of principles ...
ai-mn146:13.9_0: and equanimity, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.
ai-mn146:13.10_0: It is by developing and cultivating these seven awakening factors that a mendicant realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.”
ai-mn146:14.1_0: Then after giving this advice to the nuns, Nandaka dismissed them, saying,
ai-mn146:14.3_0: And then those nuns approved and agreed with what Nandaka had said.
ai-mn146:14.3_2: While they were standing on one side the Fortunate One said this to the nuns:
ai-mn146:14.5_0: Then those nuns bowed to the Buddha respectfully circled him, keeping him on their right, before departing.
ai-mn146:15.1_0: Then, not long after those nuns had departed, the Fortunate One addressed the monks:
ai-mn146:15.2_0: “Suppose, mendicants, it was the sabbath of the fourteenth, so many people wouldn’t get lots of people
ai-mn146:15.3_0: wondering whether the moon is full or not, since it is obviously not full.
ai-mn146:15.4_0: In the same way, those nuns were uplifted by Nandaka’s Dhamma teaching, but they still haven’t found what they’re looking for.”
ai-mn146:16.1_0: Then the Fortunate One addressed the venerable Nandaka,
ai-mn146:16.2_0: “Well then, Nandaka, tomorrow you should give those nuns the same advice again.”
ai-mn146:16.4_0: And the next day he went to those nuns, and all unfolded just like the previous day.
ai-mn146:16.5_0: Then, after the meal, on his return from alms-round, he went to his own king’s monastery.
ai-mn146:16.6_0: Those nuns saw him coming off in the distance,
ai-mn146:16.7_0: so they spread out a seat and placed water for washing the feet.
ai-mn146:16.8_0: Nandaka sat down on the seat spread out,
ai-mn146:16.10_0: Those nuns bowed, and sat down to one side.
ai-mn146:16.11_0: While sitting on one side venerable Nandaka said this to those nuns:
ai-mn146:16.12_0: “Sisters, this will be a talk in which I put questions,
ai-mn146:16.13_0: herein, when you understand, you should say: ‘We don’t understand.’
ai-mn146:16.14_0: But if for you there is doubt or uncertainty herein you should ask in return:
ai-mn146:16.15_0: ‘Why, sir, does it say this? What does that mean?’”
ai-mn146:16.16_0: “We’re already delighted and satisfied with Venerable Nandaka, since he invites us like this.”
ai-mn146:17-18.1_0: “What do you think of this, sisters, is the eye permanent or impermanent?”
ai-mn146:17-18.3_0: “But if they're impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-mn146:17-18.5_0: “But if they're impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-mn146:17-18.6_0: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-mn146:17-18.10_0: Is the nose permanent or impermanent?”
ai-mn146:17-18.16_0: “But if they're impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-mn146:17-18.18_0: “But if they're impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-mn146:17-18.19_0: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-mn146:17-18.22_0: Because we have already truly seen this with right wisdom:
ai-mn146:17-18.23_0: ‘So these six interior sense fields are impermanent.’”
ai-mn146:17-18.25_0: That’s how it is for a noble disciple who truly sees with right wisdom.
ai-mn146:19-20.1_0: What do you think of this, sisters, are sights permanent or impermanent?”
ai-mn146:19-20.3_0: “But if they're impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-mn146:19-20.5_0: “But if they're impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-mn146:19-20.6_0: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”

ai-mn146:19-20.21_0: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-mn146:19-20.24_0: Because we have already truly seen this with right wisdom:
ai-mn146:19-20.25_0: ‘So these six exterior sense fields are impermanent.’”
ai-mn146:19-20.27_0: That’s how it is for a noble disciple who truly sees with right wisdom.
ai-mn146:21.1_0: What do you think of this, sisters, is eye consciousness permanent or impermanent?”
ai-mn146:21.11_0: Is mind consciousness permanent or impermanent?”
ai-mn146:21.13_0: “But if they're impermanent, are they suffering or happiness?”
ai-mn146:21.15_0: “But if they're impermanent, suffering, and perishable, are they fit to be regarded thus:
ai-mn146:21.16_0: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
ai-mn146:21.19_0: Because we have already truly seen this with right wisdom:
ai-mn146:21.20_0: ‘So these six classes of consciousness are impermanent.’”
ai-mn146:21.22_0: That’s how it is for a noble disciple who truly sees with right wisdom.
ai-mn146:22.1_0: Suppose there was an oil lamp burning. The oil, wick, flame, and light were all impermanent and perishable.
ai-mn146:22.2_0: He who would say this, sisters:
ai-mn146:22.3_0: ‘For this oil lamp that is burning the oil, wick, and changeable,
ai-mn146:22.4_0: But the light is permanent, lasting, eternal, and imperishable.’
ai-mn146:22.8_0: Because that oil lamp’s oil, wick, and flame are all impermanent and perishable,
ai-mn146:22.10_0: “In the same way, suppose someone was to say:
ai-mn146:22.11_0: ‘These six interior sense fields are impermanent.
ai-mn146:22.12_0: But the feeling—whether pleasant, painful, or neutral—that I experience due to these six fields is permanent, lasting, eternal, and imperishable.’
ai-mn146:22.16_0: Because each kind of feeling arises dependent on the corresponding condition.
ai-mn146:22.17_0: When the corresponding condition ceases, the appropriate feeling ceases.”
ai-mn146:22.19_0: That’s how it is for a noble disciple who truly sees with right wisdom.
ai-mn146:23.1_0: Suppose there was a large tree standing with heartwood. The roots, trunk, and branches and leaves are all impermanent and perishable.
ai-mn146:23.2_0: He who would say this, sisters:
ai-mn146:23.3_0: ‘There’s a large tree standing with heartwood. The roots, trunk, and branches and leaves are all impermanent and perishable.
ai-mn146:23.4_0: But the shadow is permanent, lasting, eternal, and imperishable.’
ai-mn146:23.8_0: Because that large tree’s roots, trunk, and branches and leaves are all impermanent and perishable,
ai-mn146:23.9_0: what to say of its shadow being impermanent and changeable?”
ai-mn146:23.10_0: “In the same way, suppose someone was to say:
ai-mn146:23.11_0: ‘These six exterior sense fields are impermanent.
ai-mn146:23.12_0: But the feeling—whether pleasant, painful, or neutral—that I experience due to these exterior sense fields is permanent, lasting, eternal, and imperishable.’
ai-mn146:23.16_0: Because each kind of feeling arises dependent on the corresponding condition.
ai-mn146:23.17_0: When the corresponding condition ceases, the appropriate feeling ceases.”
ai-mn146:23.19_0: That’s how it is for a noble disciple who truly sees with right wisdom.
ai-mn146:24.1_0: Suppose a deft butcher or their apprentice was to kill a cow and carve it with a sharp meat cleaver. Without damaging the flesh inside or the hide outside,
ai-mn146:24.2_0: they’d cut, carve, sever, and slice through the connecting tendons, sinews, and ligaments,
ai-mn146:24.3_0: and then peel off the outer hide. Then they’d wrap that cow up in that very same hide and say:
ai-mn146:24.4_0: ‘This cow is joined to its hide just like before.’
ai-mn146:24.8_0: For that a deft butcher or their apprentice was to kill a cow and carve it with a sharp meat cleaver.
ai-mn146:24.9_0: they’d cut, carve, sever, and slice through the connecting tendons, sinews, and ligaments,
ai-mn146:24.10_0: and then peel off the outer hide. Then they’d wrap that cow up in that very same hide and say:
ai-mn146:24.11_0: ‘This cow is joined to its hide just like before.’
ai-mn146:24.12_0: still that cow is not joined to that hide.”
ai-mn146:25.1_0: “This is a simile I have made, sisters, to instruct in the meaning, and this is the meaning.
ai-mn146:25.2_0: ‘The interior sense fields’ is a term for the six interior sense fields.
ai-mn146:25.3_0: ‘The outer hide’ is a term for the six exterior sense fields.
ai-mn146:25.4_0: ‘The connecting tendons, sinews, and ligaments’ is a term for greed and relishing.
ai-mn146:25.5_0: ‘A sharp meat cleaver’ is a term for noble wisdom.
ai-mn146:25.6_0: And it is that noble wisdom which cuts, carves, severs, and slices the connecting corruption, fetter, and bond.
ai-mn146:26.1_0: Sisters, by developing and cultivating these seven awakening factors, a mendicant realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
ai-mn146:26.2_0: What are the teachings grouped by seven?
ai-mn146:26.3_0: It’s when a mendicant develops the awakening factors of mindfulness,
ai-mn146:26.4_0: They develop the awakening factor of investigation of principles ...
ai-mn146:26.9_0: and equanimity, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.
ai-mn146:26.10_0: It is by developing and cultivating these seven awakening factors that a mendicant realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.”
ai-mn146:26.11_0: Then after giving this advice to the nuns, Nandaka dismissed them, saying,
ai-mn146:26.13_0: And then those nuns approved and agreed with what Nandaka had said.
ai-mn146:26.13_2: While they were standing on one side the Fortunate One said this to the nuns:
ai-mn146:26.15_0: Then those nuns bowed to the Buddha respectfully circled him, keeping him on their right, before departing.
ai-mn146:27.1_0: Then, not long after those nuns had departed, the Fortunate One addressed the monks:
ai-mn146:27.2_0: “Suppose, mendicants, it was the sabbath of the fifteenth day. You wouldn’t get lots of people
ai-mn146:27.3_0: wondering whether the moon is full or not, since it is obviously not full.
ai-mn146:27.4_0: In the same way, those nuns were uplifted by Nandaka’s Dhamma teaching, and they found what they’re looking for.
ai-mn146:27.5_0: Even the last of these five hundred nuns is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening.”
ai-mn146:27.6_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-mn146:27.7_0: Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.
ai-mn146:27.8_0: The fourth section on Nandaka is finished.
